titleStmt.title: Inscription in honour of Valentinianus II from Aphrodisias by Tatianus praet. praefect

availability.licence: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

summary.term: Honorary inscription to the emperor Valentinianus II

layout.p: The column, re-used as a statue base, is broken in two parts below the inscription. The surface is badly worn and the inscribed letters are difficult to read.
layout.rs: Fragmentary: lines from 7 to 12 have been deliberately effaced.

history.provenance: Aphrodisias, South Agora, center of West stoa (in front of entrance to the courtyard of the Hadrianic Baths)

div.ab:
ἀγαθῇ τύχῃ·
τὸν τῆς ὑφ’ ἡλίῳ γῆς
αὐτοκράτορα καὶ τροπεοῦχον
δεσπότην ἡμῶν
Φλάουιον Οὐαλλεντινιανὸν
τὸν αἰώνιον Αὔγουστον,
Φλάουιος Εὐτόλμιος Τατιανὸς
ὁ λαμπρότατος ἔπαρχος τοῦ ἱεροῦ
πρετωρίου τῇ συνήθει
καθοσιώσει ἀφιέρωσεν,
ἐπὶ Ἀντωνίου Πρίσκου
τοῦ λαμπροτάτου ἡγεμόνος.

div.p: This edition follows the Roueché text (Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity, nr. 27).

app.note: Mendel did not copy Φλ or the superfluous λ in Οὐαλλεντινιανόν; Boulanger recorded both.
have been erased. Grégoire was unaware of this erasure; Mendel saw three lines erased (“3 lignes martelées”), Boulanger recorded two.

div.p: “Alla Sorte propizia! All’imperatore della Terra sotto il sole, e nostro vittorioso signore, Flavius Valentinianus, l’eterno Augusto, Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, il chiarissimo prefetto del sacro pretorio con la consueta devozione consacrò (la statua), mentre era chiarissimo governatore Antonius Priscus.”

“May Fortune be propitious! To the emperor of (all) the earth under the sun, and our victorious master, Flavius Valentinianus, the eternal Augustus, Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, of clarissimus rank, prefect of the sacred praetorium, dedicated (this statue) with the customary devotion, in the time of Antonius Priscus, governor of clarissimus rank.”

“Que la Fortune soit favorable! À l’empereur de la Terre sous le soleil, et notre seigneur victorieux, Flavius Valentinianus l’éternel Auguste, Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, le clarissime préfet du prétoire sacré avec la dévotion habituelle a consacré (la statue), alors qu’il était gouverneur clarissime Antonius Priscus.”

The column on which the inscription is engraved was found in 1905 by G. Mendel, in the context of the NYU excavations. It was and remains in the West stoa of the South agora, in the Hadrianic Baths. This column base supporting the Valentinianus II’ statue was flanked by a similar column base for Arcadius’ statue (PPRET 83), located in the southern side of the staircase.

The inscription was excavated and transcribed by Mendel in 1905 and copied by Boulanger (Notebook A, 61, no. 22, whence B, 3, nr. 2); it was subsequently copied by J. and L. Robert and finally recorded by the NYU expedition.

Our inscription was published for the first time by Mendel in the Catalogue des sculptures greques, romaines et byzantines nr. 506.2; then by H. Grégoire in Recueil des inscriptions Grecques Chrétiennes d’Asie Mineure nr. 276, from Mendel’s copy. L. Robert published the inscription in Hellenica IV, 50-51, whence BE 1949.178; by Roueché, Aphrodisias in Late Antiquity, 27, and Plate VII, whence PHI 662.

The honorary inscription for the emperor Valentinianus II was one of a group dedicated to the Theodosian imperial family (see also PPRET 82, 83) and erected by Flavius Eutolmius Tatianus, whose name was erased. The career of this distinguised figure is fully recorded in an inscription from Sidyma in Lycia (see PPRET 87). He was made praetorian prefect in the East in 388 AD and fell from power in 392 AD. He suffered damnatio memoriae and banishment to Lycia, but he was rehabilitated posthumously by his grandson with an inscription in Aphrodisia (PPRET 91). Antonius Priscus, governor of the Caria (PLRE I, p. 730), is known only by the series of the three inscriptions dedicated by Tatianus at Aphrodisias (PPRET 82-84).

Mecella M., L’amministrazione di Taziano e Proculo e il destino dei Lici tra Teodosio e Arcadio, in Governare e riformare l’impero al momento della sua divisione: Oriente, Occidente, Illirico Roma, 2015

div.p: ὀ λαμπρότατος ἔπαρ̣χος τοῦ ἱεροῦ πρετωρίου
